question: Prove that for any sets $A$ and $B$, $A \cup B = B \cup (A \setminus B)$. (Set Theory)
Prove that if $A \subseteq B$ and $B \subseteq C$, then $A \subseteq C$. (Set Theory)
Prove the Distributive Law for sets: $A \cap (B \cup C) = (A \cap B) \cup (A \cap C)$. (Set Theory)
Prove De Morgan's Law for sets: $(A \cup B)^c = A^c \cap B^c$. (Set Theory)
Prove that $A \setminus (B \cup C) = (A \setminus B) \cap (A \setminus C)$. (Set Theory)
Prove that the intersection of the power sets is the power set of the intersection: $\mathcal{P}(A) \cap \mathcal{P}(B) = \mathcal{P}(A \cap B)$. (Set Theory)
Prove that $A 	imes (B \cap C) = (A 	imes B) \cap (A 	imes C)$. (Set Theory)
Prove the definition of symmetric difference: $A 	riangle B = (A \setminus B) \cup (B \setminus A)$. (Set Theory)
Prove that $A \subseteq B$ if and only if $A \cap B = A$. (Set Theory)
Prove that if $A \subseteq B$, then $A \cup C \subseteq B \cup C$ for any set $C$. (Set Theory)
Prove that the square of any odd integer is of the form $8k + 1$ for some integer $k$. (Number Theory)
Prove that if $a \mid b$ and $b \mid c$, then $a \mid c$. (Number Theory)
Prove that $\sqrt{2}$ is irrational. (Proof by Contradiction)
Prove that the sum of two rational numbers is rational. (Number Theory)
Prove that there are infinitely many prime numbers. (Euclid's Proof)
Prove by induction that for all integers $n \ge 1$, $\sum_{i=1}^{n} i =  rac{n(n+1)}{2}$. (Number Theory)
Prove by induction that for all integers $n \ge 4$, $2^n < n!$. (Number Theory)
Prove that for any integer $n$, $3 \mid (n^3 - n)$. (Number Theory)
Prove that if $a \equiv b \pmod m$, then $a^2 \equiv b^2 \pmod m$. (Number Theory)
Prove that $\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(a, b-a)$ for any non-zero integers $a$ and $b$. (Number Theory)
Prove that the product of two even integers is divisible by 4. (Number Theory)
Prove that if $n^2$ is even, then $n$ is even. (Proof by Contrapositive)
Prove that $5 \mid (n^5 - n)$ for any integer $n$. (Number Theory)
Prove that if $p$ is a prime and $p \mid ab$, then $p \mid a$ or $p \mid b$. (Number Theory, Euclid's Lemma)
Prove by induction that the sum of the first $n$ odd positive integers is $n^2$: $\sum_{i=1}^{n} (2i-1) = n^2$. (Number Theory)
Prove using the $\epsilon-\delta$ definition that $\lim_{x 	o 3} (2x + 1) = 7$. (Real Analysis)
Prove using the $\epsilon-N$ definition that the sequence $a_n =  rac{1}{n}$ converges to $0$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the function $f(x) = x^2$ is continuous at $x=c$ for any $c \in \mathbb{R}$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that if a sequence $\{a_n\}$ converges, then it is bounded. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the sum of two continuous functions is continuous. (Real Analysis)
Prove using the $\epsilon-N$ definition that $\lim_{n 	o \infty}  rac{2n+1}{n+5} = 2$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the derivative of $f(x) = x^2$ is $f'(x) = 2x$ using the limit definition of the derivative. (Calculus)
Prove the Intermediate Value Theorem (IVT): If $f: [a, b] 	o \mathbb{R}$ is continuous and $f(a)f(b) < 0$, then there exists $c \in (a, b)$ such that $f(c) = 0$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that every convergent sequence is a Cauchy sequence. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$ is uncountable. (Cantor's Diagonalization Argument)
Prove that the composition of two continuous functions is continuous. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the limit of a sequence is unique. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the function $f(x) = |x|$ is continuous everywhere but not differentiable at $x=0$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that $e^x \ge 1 + x$ for all $x \in \mathbb{R}$. (Calculus/Analysis)
Prove the Extreme Value Theorem (EVT): If $f(x)$ is continuous on the closed interval $[a, b]$, it attains both a maximum and a minimum value on $[a, b]$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the identity element in a group is unique. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that every element in a group has a unique inverse. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the set of $2 	imes 2$ matrices with real entries forms a group under matrix addition. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the intersection of any two subgroups is a subgroup. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that in an abelian group $G$, $(ab)^n = a^n b^n$ for all $a, b \in G$ and all integers $n$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the set $\{1, -1\}$ forms a group under standard multiplication. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the center of a group $Z(G) = \{g \in G \mid gx = xg 	ext{ for all } x \in G\}$ is a subgroup of $G$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that every cyclic group is abelian. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove the Subgroup Criterion: A non-empty subset $H$ of a group $G$ is a subgroup if and only if for all $a, b \in H$, $ab^{-1} \in H$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the mapping $\phi: \mathbb{Z} 	o \mathbb{Z}_n$ defined by $\phi(x) = x \pmod n$ is a group homomorphism under addition. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that a group $G$ is abelian if and only if $(ab)^2 = a^2 b^2$ for all $a, b \in G$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the kernel of a group homomorphism is a subgroup. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the set of even integers $2\mathbb{Z}$ is a subring of the ring of integers $\mathbb{Z}$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that $\mathbb{Z}_p$ (the integers modulo $p$) is a field if and only if $p$ is a prime number. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that if $g^2 = e$ for all elements $g$ in a group $G$, then $G$ is abelian. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the set of all $n 	imes m$ matrices with real entries forms a vector space under matrix addition and scalar multiplication. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the zero vector $\mathbf{0}$ in a vector space is unique. (Linear Algebra)

Prove that if $S = \{\mathbf{v}_1, \mathbf{v}_2, \ldots, \mathbf{v}_k\}$ is a linearly independent set of vectors, then $\mathbf{v}_1 
e \mathbf{0}$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that if a set of $n$ vectors spans a vector space $V$, then any set of $n+1$ vectors in $V$ is linearly dependent. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the determinant of a $2 	imes 2$ matrix $A$ is zero if and only if the rows of $A$ are linearly dependent. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the set $W = \{(x, y, z) \in \mathbb{R}^3 \mid x+y+z=0\}$ is a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^3$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that if $A$ and $B$ are invertible $n 	imes n$ matrices, then $AB$ is invertible and $(AB)^{-1} = B^{-1}A^{-1}$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that for any two $n 	imes n$ matrices $A$ and $B$, $\det(AB) = \det(A) \det(B)$. (Linear Algebra)

Prove that a square matrix $A$ is invertible if and only if $\det(A) 
e 0$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the image (range) of a linear transformation $T: V 	o W$ is a subspace of $W$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the null space (kernel) of a linear transformation $T: V 	o W$ is a subspace of $V$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the eigenvalues of a symmetric matrix are real. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that if $\lambda$ is an eigenvalue of $A$, then $\lambda^2$ is an eigenvalue of $A^2$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that a basis for a vector space is a linearly independent set that spans the space. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that if a vector space $V$ has a basis of $n$ vectors, then every basis of $V$ has $n$ vectors. (Linear Algebra)

Prove the logical equivalence: $P 	o Q \equiv 
eg Q 	o 
eg P$. (Logic/Contrapositive)

Prove De Morgan's Law for Logic: $
eg (P \land Q) \equiv 
eg P \lor 
eg Q$. (Logic)
Prove that for all real numbers $x$, if $x > 3$, then $x^2 > 9$. (Logic/Real Numbers)
Prove that if $m$ and $n$ are integers, $m^2 - n^2$ is odd if and only if $m$ and $n$ have different parity. (Logic/Number Theory)

Prove that for any statement $P$, $P \lor 
eg P$ is a tautology. (Logic)
Prove that if the conclusion of an implication is true, the implication itself is true. (Logic)
Prove that if $P \land Q$ is true, then $P \lor Q$ is true. (Logic)
Prove that for a function $f: A 	o B$, $f(A_1 \cap A_2) \subseteq f(A_1) \cap f(A_2)$ for any subsets $A_1, A_2 \subseteq A$. (Functions/Logic)
Prove that for a function $f: A 	o B$, $f^{-1}(B_1 \cup B_2) = f^{-1}(B_1) \cup f^{-1}(B_2)$ for any subsets $B_1, B_2 \subseteq B$. (Functions/Logic)
Prove that the Well-Ordering Principle (WOP) is equivalent to the Principle of Mathematical Induction (PMI). (Foundations)
Prove the Pigeonhole Principle: If $n$ items are put into $m$ containers, with $n > m$, then at least one container must contain more than one item. (Combinatorics)
Prove that a connected graph $G$ is a tree if and only if it has $n-1$ edges, where $n$ is the number of vertices. (Graph Theory)
Prove the Handshaking Lemma: In any graph, the sum of the degrees of the vertices is equal to twice the number of edges. (Graph Theory)
Prove by induction that a set with $n$ elements has $2^n$ subsets. (Combinatorics)
Prove that the number of edges in a complete graph $K_n$ is $ rac{n(n-1)}{2}$. (Graph Theory/Combinatorics)
Prove that if a graph has $n$ vertices and is connected, it must have at least $n-1$ edges. (Graph Theory)
Prove that any tree with at least two vertices has at least two leaves (vertices of degree 1). (Graph Theory)
Prove that for non-negative integers $n$ and $k$ with $0 \le k \le n$, $ inom{n}{k} =  inom{n}{n-k}$. (Combinatorics)
Prove Pascal's Identity: $ inom{n}{k} =  inom{n-1}{k-1} +  inom{n-1}{k}$ for $1 \le k \le n$. (Combinatorics)
Prove that any closed walk in a graph contains a cycle. (Graph Theory)
Prove that a function $f: A 	o B$ is injective (one-to-one) if and only if for all subsets $C \subseteq A$, $f^{-1}(f(C)) = C$. (Functions)
Prove that the open interval $(0, 1)$ has the same cardinality as the set of real numbers $\mathbb{R}$. (Cardinality)
Prove that if a function $f: A 	o B$ is bijective, then its inverse $f^{-1}: B 	o A$ is also bijective. (Functions)
Prove that the complex conjugate of the product of two complex numbers is the product of their complex conjugates: $\overline{z_1 z_2} = \overline{z_1} \overline{z_2}$. (Complex Analysis)
Prove that if $z$ is a complex number, then $z \cdot \overline{z} = |z|^2$. (Complex Analysis)
Prove that the union of two countable sets is countable. (Cardinality)
Prove that every nonzero real number has a multiplicative inverse. (Field Axioms)
Prove that if $a, b, c$ are real numbers and $a > b$ and $c < 0$, then $ac < bc$. (Inequalities)
Prove that if $f: A 	o B$ and $g: B 	o C$ are injective functions, then their composition $g \circ f: A 	o C$ is also injective. (Functions)
Prove that a function $f: A 	o B$ is surjective (onto) if and only if $f(A)=B$. (Functions)
Prove that the only idempotent element in a group $G$ (i.e., $x$ such that $x^2 = x$) is the identity element $e$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that if $n$ is a positive integer, then $n$ is odd if and only if $n^2$ is odd. (Number Theory)
Prove that for any three integers $a, b, c$, if $a \mid b$ and $a \mid c$, then $a \mid (b+c)$. (Number Theory)
Prove that the empty set $\emptyset$ is a subset of every set $A$. (Set Theory)
Prove that if $A$ is a finite set, then $|A| < |\mathcal{P}(A)|$. (Cardinality/Set Theory)
Prove that the product of four consecutive integers is always divisible by 24. (Number Theory)
Prove that the function $f(x) =  rac{1}{x}$ on $(0, \infty)$ is injective. (Functions)
Prove that if $\lambda$ is an eigenvalue of an orthogonal matrix $Q$, then $|\lambda|=1$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that every subset of a linearly independent set is linearly independent. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that $\lim_{x 	o \infty}  rac{1}{x} = 0$ using the formal definition of a limit at infinity. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the alternating harmonic series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}  rac{(-1)^{n+1}}{n}$ converges. (Real Analysis)
Prove that every subgroup of a cyclic group is cyclic. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove Lagrange's Theorem: If $G$ is a finite group and $H$ is a subgroup of $G$, then $|H|$ divides $|G|$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the graph $K_5$ (the complete graph on 5 vertices) is non-planar. (Graph Theory)
Prove that if $v$ is a vertex of degree $k$ in a graph $G$, then $v$ is incident to $k$ edges. (Graph Theory)
Prove that the sum of the interior angles of a convex $n$-sided polygon is $(n-2) \cdot 180^{\circ}$ by induction. (Geometry/Induction)
Prove that if $x$ is a positive real number, then $x +  rac{1}{x} \ge 2$. (Inequalities)
Prove that for any integer $n$, $n^2 + n + 1$ is always odd. (Number Theory)
Prove that if $x$ is an element of a group $G$ and $x^k = e$ for some integer $k$, then the order of $x$ divides $k$. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that the set of all polynomials of degree at most $n$ forms a vector space. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that a sequence is convergent if and only if all its subsequences converge to the same limit. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the distance between any two distinct real numbers is positive. (Real Analysis)
Prove that if $A \subseteq B$, then $A^c \supseteq B^c$. (Set Theory)
Prove that for any three sets $A, B, C$, $A 	imes (B \cup C) = (A 	imes B) \cup (A 	imes C)$. (Set Theory)
Prove that the difference of two odd integers is an even integer. (Number Theory)

Prove that if $n$ is a perfect square, then $n 
ot\equiv 2 \pmod 3$. (Number Theory)
Prove that if $A$ is an $n 	imes n$ matrix, then $A + A^T$ is a symmetric matrix. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that the null space and the column space of a matrix $A$ only intersect at the zero vector, i.e., $	ext{Null}(A) \cap 	ext{Col}(A) = \{\mathbf{0}\}$. (Linear Algebra)
Prove that if $f$ and $g$ are surjective functions, their composition $g \circ f$ is also surjective. (Functions)
Prove that $\sum_{i=0}^{n}  inom{n}{i} = 2^n$. (Combinatorics/Binomial Theorem)
Prove that every non-trivial connected graph has at least one spanning tree. (Graph Theory)
Prove that the set of even integers $2\mathbb{Z}$ is countable. (Cardinality)
Prove that if $x$ is a real number, then $x^2 \ge 0$. (Real Analysis)
Prove that the multiplicative inverse of a non-zero element in a field is unique. (Abstract Algebra)
Prove that for any integers $a$ and $b$, $\gcd(a, b) = \gcd(|a|, |b|)$. (Number Theory)
Prove that the empty set is unique. (Set Theory)
